This is the type of employee that shows passive aggression. This is the same individual that will run to leadership “acting concerned about you”. Creating an issue with you for no reason. Asking for help was always a problem when they find you as a threat. Maybe the company is not all bad. However, the two locations In which I was employed were horrible. I got terminated after my entire shift stating that I was not a good fit the team, and that management had to do what was best for the team. The irony is that they do not even know who is on their team. Unless, you were just like them to get ahead. My Customer service was top tier and not even one complaint. What was the real reason? Asking for help and leadership copped an attitude? Expressing aggression? They have poor conflict management skills. My culture and values obviously did not align with the company, and that is okay. I have high reason to believe my termination was very personal.

review_title: A well-run project management office in a large, stable company.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Advocate Aurora Health is one of the largest medical organizations in the United States, with hundreds of locations in Illinois and Wisconsin. It has 76,000 employees overall and about 1,600 in the IT department. The project management office (PMO) has about fifty people. It is well run, with processes in place for project intake, prioritization, and capacity planning. The staff is a diverse mix of people who are good at what they do. The culture is good. People are willing to share information. There is very little drama. The PMO Director, Shibani Tripathi, is excellent. The larger company is secure and stable. The COVID-19 period was difficult for medical organizations, but AAH weathered through it well. It never felt like people in the PMO might lose their jobs.
cons: Because the organization is so large, the people at the top are powerful. It feels like decisions are driven by personalities and not planning. There is a culture at the top that says change is constant and everyone needs to get on board. This creates difficulties for project managers, who work with people in the middle tiers of the organization. Directors and Managers are expected to commit to timelines and stick to them, but they are constantly handed new work and expected to deliver on that too. The politics around this can play out in different ways, depending on which people are involved.

review_title: ACL Wisconsin Central Lab - Great Place to Work!
job_title: Medical Technologist in West Allis, WI
pros: I have to admit, I was hesitant to accept this job at Advocate Aurora Health for two reasons: it is SUCH a large organization and I was fearful of being just another worker bee and I had a negative experience as a patient of Aurora Health. However, I am happy that I did accept this job! The interview process was quick and easy. I came here from Washington state and they allowed me almost a month to actually move and get settled. Yes, this is a large organization with LOTS of patients and samples coming in and out of the lab. But I feel like ACL does a pretty amazing job with handling such a large sample volume. The team here in the lab is incredibly supportive and open to questions - I never feel like I am bothering anybody (and I ask a lot of questions). The lab leadership has a constant but not oppressive presence in the lab such that I feel supported when I have difficult situations arise. The benefits are some of the best I've seen for this position!
cons: Ergonomics - I wish the lab had more opportunities to alleviate the sitting position, such as standing desks or adjustable table tops. PTO - Granted, I am new here (I only started three months ago), but I find it difficult to get time off. Staffing - I think we are a bit short staffed here, which I think is happening in labs across the country (my last job was short staffed, too) which can lead to burn-out and stress and may be contributing to the PTO issue.

They just don't have their act together. They also don't respect themselves enough so they take second-hand judgement as their own so it's hard to respect them. Health insurance sucks.Since they switched managements,(which they do often, apparently) I felt bullied, unappreciated, made me feel targeted without saying anything mean towards my kind. Since the switch I had to be on certain medication to help me put up with them and I come home depressed. The aurora provider who took care of me, the former management, my preceptors, and EAP all advised me to report to HR so I tried to get HR to help me but they ignored me. My coworkers who I work alongside with were also ignored when they tried to defend me. I was being sent to many places also even though I was not a float and mileage were never paid. They also don't try to cover other workers so there were time I had to room for two providers. I decided to not let them control my life and left. I will miss the nurses I work with and continue to appreciate the support they gave me.

job_title: Staff RN in Chicago, IL
pros: There aren’t any at this time.
cons:
I used to believe advocate cared about its employees during the pandemic. I no longer do. With this most recent surge, my coworkers submitted a request for hazard pay. 

The response was a virtual town hall with our CNO and manager gaslighting us. They did not arrive prepared. We were shown a graph with questionable math. We were told our covid patients aren’t as bad as they used to be. We would make more money if we picked up an extra shift every week for 52 weeks. Meanwhile, some of us cannot even make it out of bed on our days off learning to live with PTSD. We were told we would have more money if we would just refer nurses for the referral bonus, as though it is our job to staff the hospital. It was humiliating to be spoken to this way.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Milwaukee, WI
pros:
I work for a large hospital in the system, which comes with a lot of pros d/t many resources available round the clock while on the job - on-site lab, pharmacy, HBO, dialysis, so many specialty floors that you can lean on when you have questions.

Management is great, staffing is too - of course user experience varies depending on your own personality and those of others, but overall it's a great workplace. I'm in my 30's and have worked many places so I've seen some drama and this workplace is at least always working on creating a positive working environment. There is shared nursing governance so if you want to get involved in change, you can. Lots of opportunities to try different specialties and supportive management that actively encourages professional growth and wants to help you if you decide to try something else. They recently hired a new CNO and she is very approachable and has made such a good impression on me and others, very sweet person and already advocating for us.

Matrix on my floor is great. Being a larger hospital, you do get sicker people, very excellent, challenging learning experience and you WILL leave this job prepared for anything the world can throw at you. I came as a new grad (they have a lot of new grad opportunities) and many travelers and float staff will tell you that if you can handle this, you can handle anything. Highly recommend to all new grads or experienced nurses looking for something more exciting/challenging.
cons: More challenging patient population, can be stressful, but then again what nursing job isn't!

job_title: Anonymous in West Allis, WI
pros: I overall enjoyed the work I did, had a close bond with my team, and felt valued by my supervisor.
cons:
Biggest thing: STRESS AND TURNOVER. 

Ever since the merger, the focus on money-making became ridiculous. No paid holidays, and no time and a half if you had to work the holidays-all you got was a measly $5 coupon for the cafeteria and the option to use your PTO if you wanted extra pay.

And of course the biggest issue facing every healthcare corporation now is the C19 vaccine mandate. For a company that touts “Excellence, Compassion and Respect” as well as supposedly being diverse, inclusive, and non-discriminatory, there was definitely zero of that when religious exemptions were filed for the vax. After denying me and many others the first exemption request, this company quoted in their appeal approval emails: “While your Religious exemption appeal is approved, we are not endeavoring to address each basis for your appeal, some of which may contain factual inaccuracies and/or basis for an exemption which, alone, would have warranted a denial.” Wow. I didn’t know these people suddenly became God and could judge my beliefs as inaccurate. For as long as I live on this earth, I will always bow before the One True God, and not to my employer who made my life a living wreck, and ultimately made me walk away from my career as a healthcare worker. “Hero to Zero” in the blink of an eye.

review_title: Telemetry: Toxic culture. Bad ratios. Not a good place to work.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Chicago, IL
pros:
I’ve heard that certain units have better staffing, better ratios, and better working conditions. 

A lot of the other nurses and PCAs were cool and helped each other out.

I’m sure worse places to work exist in the world.
cons:
Oh god.

Ratios are NOT appropriate for acuity.

Toxic management who will throw you under the bus, high turnover, and anti-union.

Acuity is increasing, yet they are also increasing ratios (fewer nurses and PCAs, but with added patients and responsibilities).

RNs and PCAs frequently unable to take their full breaks during a shift. Increasing falls because there are no sitters for highly confused patients constantly trying to get out of bed. Patients are constantly upset and unhappy because staffing is not appropriate, so patients can’t get enough attention. Then they take it out on the RNs caring for them, who are already being pushed too hard with burnout ratios.

All areas (pharmacy, phlebotomy, pcas, transport staff, cleaning staff, RNs) seemed to have high turnover and inadequate staffing, and talk about how they are unhappy and want to quit.

If you speak to management they will do absolutely nothing (maybe buy the unit pizza) to fix anything - Management says “just do your best” with inadequate staffing, but will be the first to throw you under the bus if something goes wrong because of it. You will be blamed for the repercussions of the hospital inadequately staffing the units and not setting appropriate ratios. 

When you have to work short staffed, will you get paid more, since you are taking on the duties of 1-2 nurses? Absolutely not. The hospital will just profit extra off of you trying to be multiple people at once. People constantly leaving the unit and new staff constantly coming. Half the floor will be new by the time you make it to a year… if you make it to a year (why would you stay a whole year here). You watch the light slowly die from each new person’s eyes day by day as they work here. Nurses on floor became burnt out. Many RNs don’t feel like their license is safe while working here. 

Working here was a traumatizing experience.

review_title: Perspective From a Newly Hired Employee
job_title: Technical Support Administrator II in Park Ridge, IL
pros:
Through the past year and a half or so I was working as a contractor with AAH though Brooksource on the Windows 10 Upgrade Project, so I became familiarized with the work culture before and during the COVID pandemic. 

Although AAH has gone though its growing pains through the pandemic, especially during the stricter lockdown phases, the healthcare industry in general, being an inherently essential service, has had more consistent opportunities for work. 

As a contractor, I was able to shift from project work albeit temporarily, to providing systems such as computers and tablets for an increasing workforce that must work from home due to the pandemic and for patients to connect with their families remotely, especially when they are under quarantine. 

Yes there was some unpaid work downtime as a contractor, but it was minimized because of the essential nature of the services of this organization. Eventually lockdown restrictions eased and I was able to get back to a normal schedule.

I was able to eventually leverage my experience and networking as a contractor into a full time, permanent position in AAH in a Field Services Technician role for one of their biggest hospitals as a professional level TSA. My direct leadership is focused but fair, the team I work with are all competent workers and the work itself is very fast paced.

I consider myself fortunate to have landed a role where I am able to make significant contributions with my experience, education and skill set, while still having a wealth of things that I still need to learn.
cons:
For my role specifically, there was very little in the way of salary negotiation. Because this organization is "not for profit" they of course do their best to remain competitive in the job market for equivalent roles, but essentially "their offer was their offer" in terms of salary, with no bargaining for something higher. If I were entertaining a separate offer, I would have to take the higher salary even though this position may be more closely aligned with my skill set and career goals.

Because of the COVID pandemic, sweeping generalizations were made regarding which functional groups could work from home and which were essential in office, clinic, hospital jobs. 

There are of course types of work that can only be done in person, but there are other groups, like mine, which I would consider "gray areas" where much work can be done from home with little lack of efficiency or productivity, but even spending one of the five work days a week from home can be frowned upon and only seems to be allowed under special circumstances. It seems unfair given the ability of a good portion of the workforce that already WFH efficiently, to not be able to accomplish at least part of our workload from home. 

To be fair, too much of one thing or another can be monotonous, if I spent every day from months on end either WFH or at office exclusively for weeks or months on end, the possibility exists that I may get bored of it. A little of both certainly can't hurt worker morale or their ability to do their work. It may actually even help.

In comparison with my former position in a "for profit" LLC, salary employees are able to log and "bank" overtime hours, with the option to either collect straight time pay or use those banked hours as PTO. This allowed salaried workers of that company to be able to put in necessary hours during project "crunch" time but be compensated in extra pay or extra time off later on. 

Early on I simply lost track of all the times I have stayed late tying up loose ends and not leaving work for the next day. I typically spend 30 minutes to a couple of hours at the end of my shift each day wrapping up my work, and catching up on ancillary items like email follow ups, mandatory training, knowledge enhancing and logging details of my work so I don't have to proverbially "reinvent the wheel" if I encounter a similar problem solving issue in the future. 

Nowadays, it's a little bit better, because we are now proactively logging in our time spent doing various tasks per day including, time spent training, in meetings, any overtime and time spend resolving "emergency" technical issues. There of course is no compensation for the overtime logged, but at least management as a record of the effort we may put fourth, especially when we are inundated with technical, incidents, requests and project work. But I can only hope the data and knowledge is used judiciously and those that actually put in the extra effort are somehow recognized.

job_title: Postdoctoral Psychology Fellow in Chicago, IL
pros: Positive, healthy and supportive work team culture. Competitive pay and benefits. Values and mission driven organization. I get to do what I love and get paid well to do it!
cons:
While the current support staff is AMAZING! Psychology clinics do not have appropriately sized support staff teams. This results in doctors and clinicians being required to spend what could be patient care time completing administrative work that Advocate's system has organized into support staff responsibilities. Research shows that best practice is to have every team member working to the limits of their capacity which frees up the next level to work in a more efficacious way. 

 Everything we do requires technology that often does not work properly and IT on average takes an hour waiting on hold just to get onto their call back list. If they call you back and you do not answer because it is after hours or you are with a patient they close the ticket and you need to start over. They do not provide information or an opportunity to call them back. If they do get in contact with you they often do not know how to fix the issue and you are left with work arounds that increase time or difficulty when completing work tasks. Overall IT concerns are difficult to have addressed and significantly negatively impact ability to provide quality patient care due to time spent managing issues and inability to utilize systems required to provide patient care.
